container.heading: Additional Requirements for Accreditation-Based Licenses for Specific Residential Community-Based Behavioral Health Services

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter sets forth descriptions of, criteria for, and licensing requirements for, three specific programs that provide residential community-based behavioral health services. These programs shall comply with COMAR 10.63.01—.02, 10.63.04, and 10.63.06. Residential Rehabilitation Programs shall also comply with COMAR 10.63.03.09.

section.heading: Covered Programs.
section.text: This chapter applies to the following programs:

para.text: Group Homes for Adults with Mental Illness;
Residential Crisis Services (RCS) program; and
Residential Rehabilitation Program (RRP).

section.heading: Group Homes for Adults with Mental Illness.

para.text: In order to be licensed under this subtitle, a group home for adults with mental illness shall:
Meet the definition in Health-General Article, §10-514 (b), (d), and (e), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Provide a home-like, supportive residential environment:
In a small group home, which provides services for more than 3, but not more than 8 individuals with a mental health disorder; or
In a large group home for more than 8, but not more than 16 individuals with a mental health disorder; and
Meet the site requirements set out in Regulation .07 of this chapter verified through an annual site inspection conducted by the CSA or LBHA.

A group home for adults with mental illness may not provide services for individuals with a primary diagnosis of developmental disability, as defined in Health-General Article, §7-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Residential Crisis Services (RCS).
section.text: In order to be licensed under this subtitle, a residential crisis services program:

para.text: Shall provide short-term mental health treatment and support services in a structured environment for individuals who require 24-hour supervision due to a psychiatric crisis;
Shall be designed to:
Prevent psychiatric inpatient admission;
Shorten the length of inpatient stay;
Effectively use general hospital emergency departments; and
Provide an alternative to psychiatric inpatient admission;
Shall have staff who are on-site 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, whenever an individual is on-site receiving services;
For adults, shall meet the site requirements set out in Regulation .07 of this chapter verified through an annual site inspection conducted by the CSA or LBHA; and
For individuals younger than 21 years old, may offer services in an appropriately licensed therapeutic program, as appropriate.

section.heading: Residential Rehabilitation Program (RRP).
section.text: In order to be licensed under this subtitle, a residential rehabilitation program (RRP) shall:

para.text: Serve individuals with a mental disorder;
Be operated by a licensed PRP-A;
Lease or own the RRP sites;
Be approved by BHA for RRP funding;
Provide a home-like, supportive residential environment;
Provide services for no more than 3 individuals per RRP site, unless also licensed as a group home as provided in Regulation .03 of this chapter;
Promote the individual’s ability to engage and participate in appropriate community activities;
Enable the individual to develop the daily living skills needed for independent functioning;
Have:
On-site staffing, as needed to meet the needs of the individuals served; and
Staff that are available on call, 24 hours per day, 7 days per week;
Meet the site requirements as set out in Regulation .07 of this chapter, verified through an annual site inspection conducted by the CSA or LBHA, as appropriate;

Have a written policy regarding the development of and process for implementation of a managed intervention plan (MIP) for an individual receiving residential services who may be at risk of an unplanned discharge, which:
Is developed in collaboration with the individual, treatment team members, and CSA or LBHA, as appropriate; and
Includes a description of additional individualized services and supports that may be needed, and identification of temporary residential alternatives, if any; and
If an MIP is executed, develop a transition plan that:
Is created in collaboration with the individual, treatment team members, CSA or LBHA, as appropriate, and ASO; and
Includes the elements outlined in §K(2) of this regulation.

section.heading: Application Requirements for a Residence to be Operated by a Program.
section.text: A program seeking a license under this subtitle for a residential site shall submit to the CSA or LBHA a completed application that:

para.text: Is on the form required by the Administration with all required documents attached; and
Includes documentation that the residence:
Is owned or leased by the applicant; or
Will be owned or leased by the applicant; and
Is located in a building that will have continuous fire, liability, and hazard insurance coverage.

section.heading: Residential Site Requirements.
section.text: A program licensed to provide community-based behavioral health residential services under this chapter shall ensure that:

para.text: All areas of a residence, including storage areas:
Are safe;
Clean; and
Free of hazards and clutter;
A residence has:
No housing code or zoning violations;
Working smoke alarms or smoke detectors that meet local fire codes for residential dwellings;
Hot and cold running water:
Adequate light, heat, and ventilation; and
Sufficient, appropriate, and functional furnishings, equipment, supplies, and utensils comparable to those found in the residences of nondisabled individuals;
Each resident:
Has the resources to purchase or has access to food;
Has the resources to acquire an adequate supply of soap, towels, and toilet tissue;
Who self-administers medication, has access to a secure storage area for the resident’s medications;
Has access to a secure storage area for funds and valuables;
Has access to transportation;
Has access to a telephone in the residence; and
To the extent possible, may use personal possessions and preferences in furnishing and decorating the resident’s space.
The following emergency procedures are followed:
Posted near the telephone are telephone numbers for the:
Fire department, police, ambulance, and poison control center; and
Program’s on-call staff; and
An emergency evacuation procedure that is explained to and practiced by residents within 10 days after entering residence and, at a minimum, every 3 months after that;
Each bedroom has:
A minimum of 70 square feet for a single bedroom and a minimum of 120 square feet for a double bedroom;
An interior door, except for an efficiency apartment;
Closet space in or convenient to each bedroom for each individual using the bedroom;
Coverings for each window, for privacy;
A bed with a clean mattress and pillow for each resident using the bedroom;
At least two sets of bed linens per resident; and
Not more than two residents using the bedroom;
Each toilet and bathing area has:
A minimum of one full bathroom for every four residents; and
At least one toilet, one basin, and one tub or shower connected to hot and cold water;
Easy access and conveniently located, not more than one floor level from living, dining, and sleeping rooms; and
Privacy for the individual using it; and
The program has a written relocation plan for each site that:
Specifies where residents may live temporarily if the CSA or LBHA determines that conditions in the approved residence pose an imminent risk to the health, safety, or welfare of a resident;
Is approved by the CSA or LBHA, as appropriate; and
Is updated annually.
